Previous to a full examination of this question one might 
imagine that the circular form of the Iris would be a sufficient 
criterion of the direction in which an eye is looking, since,
when the living eye is pointed to us, this part is always 
circular, but cannot appear strictly so, when turned so 
that we view it with any degree of obliquity. But, upon 
further consideration it is evident that we cannot judge 
of exact circularity with sufficient precision for this purpose,
even when the whole circle is fully seen, & that in many cases
